newsitem.title: INDIA: India postal, phone strike seen near end.
newsitem.headline: India postal, phone strike seen near end.

text.p: A six-day-old strike by one million postal and telephone workers in India appeared close to an end after an offer from Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda to meet trade unions, a labour leader said on Monday.

O.P. Gupta, head of the National Federation of Telecom Employees (NFTE), told Reuters labour leaders had been invited through an intermediary but said a word of assurance from Deve Gowda to meet their demands was not enough.
"Even if the meeting is held (today), the strike can be called off only in the afternoon," Gupta said, adding this meant work could actually resume only on Tuesday.
A senior government official, who asked not to be identified, told Reuters the strike was expected to end later on Monday following a meeting of the unions with Deve Gowda.
But Gupta said differences within the prime minister's 13-party coalition, ranging from social democrats to communists, could hamper an early end to the strike.
Communications Minister Beni Prasad Varma belongs to the socialist Samajwadi Party. Deve Gowda belongs to the centre-left Janata Dal.
But an expected cabinet meeting on Tuesday could decide on the demand of six unions for the abolition of a 3,500-rupee ($100) ceiling on annual bonus payments, Gupta said.
The unions, three representing postal workers and three telecommunication workers, say Communications Minister Varma's promise to consider their demand was not sufficient.
The government, concerned over high interest rates and the cost of debt, had set itself an ambitious budget tightening target this year through a ceiling on bonus payments.
On the first day of the strike, Varma called the work stoppage illegal, saying the unions had not given adequate advance notice.
The strike has crippled government postal services with millions of letters piling up in post offices across the nation.
Telecommunications services, which are largely automated, have not been severely hit but operator-related services and repair and maintenance have been disrupted.
